# X (social network) **X**, formerly known as **Twitter**, is an American [social media](/article/en/Social_media) and [social networking](/article/en/Social_network) service operated by [X Corp.](/article/en/X_Corp), a United States company. It is one of the world's largest social media platforms and among the most visited websites globally, ranking between 5th and 6th in traffic depending on the measurement source. The platform enables users to publish and interact with short text messages, images, and videos through posts (commonly known as "tweets"), as well as like, repost, and reply to content from other users. ## Contents 1. [Overview](#overview) 2. [History](#history) 3. [Ownership and Corporate Structure](#ownership-and-corporate-structure) 4. [Features and Functionality](#features-and-functionality) 5. [User Demographics](#user-demographics) 6. [Technology](#technology) 7. [Moderation and Safety](#moderation-and-safety) 8. [Criticism and Controversy](#criticism-and-controversy) 9. [Impact on Society](#impact-on-society) 10. [See Also](#see-also) ## Overview X provides numerous features beyond basic posting, including [direct messaging](/article/en/Direct_message), video and audio calling, bookmarks, lists, communities, integration with the [Grok](/article/en/Grok) AI chatbot, job search functionality, and [Spaces](/article/en/Twitter_Spaces)‚Äîa social audio feature enabling live audio conversations. Users with [X Premium](/article/en/X_Premium) subscriptions can access additional capabilities such as extended character limits, post editing, reduced advertising, and monetization options. The service maintains a global user base estimated at 600 million monthly active users as of May 2024, though independent usage metrics suggest a decline of approximately 15% following [Elon Musk's](/article/en/Elon_Musk) acquisition. Different countries report varying usage patterns, with X blocked entirely in [Russia](/article/en/Russia), [Iran](/article/en/Iran), [China](/article/en/China), and [North Korea](/article/en/North_Korea), and intermittently blocked in numerous other nations including [Egypt](/article/en/Egypt), [Iraq](/article/en/Iraq), [Nigeria](/article/en/Nigeria), [Turkey](/article/en/Turkey), [Venezuela](/article/en/Venezuela), and [Turkmenistan](/article/en/Turkmenistan). ## History ### Founding (2006) Twitter was created in March 2006 by [Jack Dorsey](/article/en/Jack_Dorsey), [Noah Glass](/article/en/Noah_Glass), [Biz Stone](/article/en/Biz_Stone), and [Evan Williams](/article/en/Evan_Williams) as a research project of the [Odeo](/article/en/Odeo) company in San Francisco. Dorsey proposed the foundational concept of using [Short Message Service](/article/en/SMS) (SMS) to communicate with small groups across distances. The project's temporary name, "twttr," was attributed to Glass and inspired by the name of photo-sharing service [Flickr](/article/en/Flickr) and the five-character length of American SMS short codes. The term "Twitter" was ultimately selected, with Dorsey explaining that it combined "writing short text messages" with "the chirping of birds." The first prototype, developed by Dorsey and contractor Florian Weber, served as an internal communication tool for Odeo employees. The full public version launched on July 15, 2006. In October 2006, Stone, Williams, Dorsey, and other Odeo members established Obvious Corporation and acquired Odeo from investors and shareholders. The company dismissed Noah Glass, who remained silent about his role in Twitter's founding until 2011. Twitter spun off as an independent company in April 2007. ### Early Growth (2007-2010) The pivotal moment for Twitter's popularization occurred at the 2007 South by Southwest Interactive (SXSWi) conference in Austin, Texas. During the event, daily tweet volume surged from 20,000 to 60,000 tweets. The conference organizers displayed live tweet feeds on large plasma screens throughout the venue, attracting hundreds of attendees to experiment with the platform. The positive reception led to rapid adoption within the technology community and beyond. Growth accelerated dramatically after 2007: - By 2008, approximately 400,000 tweets were posted per quarter - In 2009, Twitter won the "Breakout of the Year" [Webby Award](/article/en/Webby_Award) - By February 2010, users were sending 50 million tweets daily - By June 2010, the platform processed approximately 65 million tweets per day (roughly 750 per second) - By September 2013, 200 million users sent over 400 million tweets daily, with nearly 60% from mobile devices Notably, on June 25, 2009, following the death of [Michael Jackson](/article/en/Michael_Jackson), the phrase "Michael Jackson" appeared in approximately 100,000 tweets within one hour, demonstrating the platform's capacity for real-time information dissemination during major events. NASA astronaut Timothy Creamer transmitted the first tweet from space aboard the [International Space Station](/article/en/International_Space_Station) on January 22, 2010. ### Platform Evolution (2010-2022) From September through October 2010, Twitter rolled out "New Twitter," a comprehensive redesign enabling users to view images and videos without leaving the platform. Subsequent updates introduced [hashtag](/article/en/Hashtag) support (2009), [Twitter Lists](/article/en/Twitter_Lists) (late 2009), [Moments](/article/en/Twitter_Moments) (2015), and [Spaces](/article/en/Twitter_Spaces) (2020)‚Äîa social audio feature allowing hosted conversations with up to 13 on-stage participants. The platform's character limit, initially set at 140 characters for SMS compatibility, was expanded to 280 characters in November 2017 for most languages, though [Chinese](/article/en/Chinese_language), [Japanese](/article/en/Japanese_language), and [Korean](/article/en/Korean_language) remained at 140. In 2023, [X Premium](/article/en/X_Premium) subscribers gained the ability to create posts up to 4,000 characters. On November 7, 2013, [Twitter, Inc.](/article/en/Twitter,_Inc.) conducted its [initial public offering](/article/en/Initial_public_offering) (IPO) on the [New York Stock Exchange](/article/en/New_York_Stock_Exchange), raising $1.8 billion. The stock opened at $26 per share and closed at $44.90, initially valuing the company at approximately $31 billion. Throughout the 2010s, Twitter experimented with numerous features: [verified account](/article/en/Verified_account) badges (introduced 2009), image captions for accessibility (2016-2022), poll functionality (2015), editing capabilities (2022), and various advertising formats. "Fleets" (ephemeral stories lasting 24 hours) launched in November 2020 but were discontinued in August 2021 due to low engagement. ### Elon Musk's Acquisition and Rebranding (2022-2024) On April 4, 2022, [Elon Musk](/article/en/Elon_Musk) acquired a 9.1% stake in Twitter for $2.64 billion, prompting a 27% stock price increase. Initially offered a board seat, Musk declined membership and instead made an unsolicited acquisition offer. After Twitter's board implemented a "poison pill" strategy to prevent hostile takeover, negotiations commenced. On April 25, 2022, Twitter's board accepted Musk's $44 billion acquisition offer ($54.20 per share). Throughout the acquisition process, Musk expressed skepticism regarding Twitter's reporting of bot and spam accounts, eventually forcing Twitter to provide extensive documentation. On October 27, 2022, the acquisition completed. Musk immediately removed all nine board members, including [Parag Agrawal](/article/en/Parag_Agrawal) (CEO), [Ned Segal](/article/en/Ned_Segal) (CFO), and Vijaya Gadde (legal/policy officer). Musk initiated sweeping changes: - **Mass Layoffs**: Reduced employees from approximately 7,500 to under 1,300 by January 2023‚Äîless than one-fifth the pre-acquisition workforce, including significant cuts to engineering and content moderation teams - **Advertising Crisis**: By December 2022, 70% of the top 100 advertisers had paused spending; American advertising revenue fell 59% year-over-year by May 2023 - **Account Verification**: Introduced paid verification through [Twitter Blue](/article/en/Twitter_Blue) subscription ($7.99/month, later $8 or $10.99 depending on platform), initially leading to impersonation crises before suspension and relaunch in December 2022 On July 23-24, 2023, Musk announced the rebrand from Twitter to **X**. The bird logo was replaced with a stylized capital letter X based on the mathematical double-struck character (Unicode U+1D54F ùïè). The domain x.com, originally Musk's online bank project acquired from [PayPal](/article/en/PayPal) in 2017, was reconfigured to redirect to twitter.com. This rebrand officially completed on May 17, 2024, when the platform's web address changed from twitter.com to x.com. [Linda Yaccarino](/article/en/Linda_Yaccarino), former NBCUniversal advertising executive, succeeded Musk as CEO on June 5, 2023, while Musk retained positions as chairman and chief technology officer (CTO). ### Recent Ownership Changes (2025) In March 2025, [xAI](/article/en/xAI) (Musk's artificial intelligence company) acquired X Corp. in an all-stock transaction valuing X at $33 billion ($45 billion including $12 billion in debt), with xAI itself valued at $80 billion. In July 2025, Yaccarino stepped down as CEO. In February 2026, [SpaceX](/article/en/SpaceX) acquired xAI, marking the sixth change in X's ownership and the third under Musk's control. ## Ownership and Corporate Structure X Corp. was established in March 2023 as the legal successor to Twitter, Inc., following Musk's acquisition. The company maintains primary operations in San Francisco, California, with over 25-26 offices worldwide (pre-acquisition figure; reduced significantly post-acquisition). ### Financial Performance Twitter's revenue sources historically centered on advertising: - 2011: Estimated $139.5 million in advertising sales - 2013: $168.6 million in third-quarter revenue (Forbes) - 2019: $3.46 billion annual revenue - 2022 Q1: $1.2 billion revenue (23% increase in advertising year-over-year to $1.11 billion) Post-acquisition advertising revenue declined sharply. According to internal documents obtained by the New York Times, American X advertising revenue from April to early May 2023 was $88 million‚Äîa 59% decrease from the same 2022 period. In May 2022, Twitter agreed to pay $150 million to settle [Federal Trade Commission](/article/en/Federal_Trade_Commission) and [Department of Justice](/article/en/Department_of_Justice) lawsuits alleging collection of users' phone numbers and email addresses ostensibly for security purposes but used for targeted advertising. In December 2025, the [European Commission](/article/en/European_Commission) fined X ‚Ç¨120 million for alleged non-compliance with the [Digital Services Act](/article/en/Digital_Services_Act). ### Shareholder Litigation In 2016, shareholders sued Twitter alleging artificial inflation of stock prices through misleading statements about user engagement. In September 2021, Twitter agreed to pay $809.5 million to settle this class-action lawsuit without admitting wrongdoing. ## Features and Functionality ### Posts and Core Interactions Posts are publicly visible by default, though publishers can restrict visibility to followers only. Users access the platform through the official website, applications, or historically via SMS in select countries. Key interactive features include: - **Reposting/Retweeting**: Sharing others' posts to personal timelines - **Quote Reposting**: Embedding another's post with added commentary (launched 2015) - **Liking**: Marking individual posts as favorites - **Replies and Mentions**: Using "@" symbol to reference other users - **Hashtags**: Using "#" prefix to categorize posts by topic (introduced 2007), with "hashflags" providing custom emojis for specific hashtags (introduced 2014, available for purchase by corporations) Users can hide replies to their posts after publishing, selecting from options: anyone can reply, only followers of the post author, verified accounts only, or specified accounts. Muting and blocking features enable users to control interactions. ### Post Editing and Character Limits Tweet editing became available to [X Premium](/article/en/X_Premium) subscribers in 2022, allowing 30-minute editing windows. The character limit evolution: - **2006-2017**: 140 characters (for SMS compatibility) - **2017-2023**: 280 characters (doubled; excludes images, videos, links from count) - **2023-present**: X Premium users access up to 4,000 characters; [Premium Plus](/article/en/X_Premium#Premium_Plus) subscribers gain additional capabilities including long-form articles ### Multimedia and Content Features **Photo and Video Sharing** - Twitter integrated photo-sharing in June 2011, allowing direct image uploads - Image captions (up to 480 characters) became accessible via screen readers or mouse hover in 2016; global availability followed in 2022 - Video streaming expanded significantly from 2016, with partnerships for NFL, MLB, WNBA, PGA Tour, and entertainment content **Polls** - Introduced in 2015, allowing up to 7 days duration with anonymous voting **Spaces** - Social audio feature (launched November 2020) enabling real-time voice conversations - Originally limited to 600+ followers; opened to all users October 2021 - Maximum 13 on-stage speakers; "Ticketed Spaces" (launched August 2021) allows hosts to charge $1-$999 for access **Fleets** - Ephemeral 24-hour stories launched November 17, 2020 - Discontinued August 2021 due to minimal adoption **X Articles** - Long-form posting feature (launched March 2024) - Supports formatting (bold, italics, strikethrough, lists) and multimedia embedding - Available to X Premium Plus subscribers and verified organizations ### Verification and Paid Tiers **Account Verification Evolution** - Introduced June 2009 with blue checkmark badges denoting official status - Redesigned systems multiple times: - July 2016: Public application process based on "public interest" - November 2020: Relaunch emphasizing "Off Twitter Notability" (Wikipedia page existence) - November 2022 (Musk): Converted to paid feature via Twitter Blue ($7.99/month, later $8/$10.99) In November 2022, Musk introduced payment-based verification, eliminating legacy verified accounts unless they subscribed. Verification requirements were reinstated in March 2023 with tiered pricing: $1,000/month for organizations (gold checkmark) plus $50 per affiliate; $84/month for individuals (blue checkmark); gray checkmarks for government and multilateral accounts. **X Premium/Premium Plus** - Twitter Blue (launched November 2021): $7.99/month initially - Renamed X Premium (August 2023): Provides editing, reduced ads, long videos, and monetization - Premium Plus (October 2023): $14/month; includes Grok AI access, X Pro (formerly TweetDeck), ad-free experience, and monetization features - Basic tier (October 2023): Similar to traditional Premium but excludes monetization and X Pro ### Additional Features **Community Notes** (formerly Birdwatch, launched January 2021) - Enables users meeting eligibility requirements to add contextual information to potentially misleading posts - Notes evaluated by community; displayed only with predominantly positive ratings - Algorithm published on GitHub demonstrating transparency commitment - Expanded globally from US-only launch; formally implemented in Japan July 6, 2023 **Lists** (added late 2009) - Enable users to follow curated author lists rather than individual accounts - Can be set public (visible in searches/profiles) or private **Moments** (introduced October 2015) - Feature allowing curation of posts into collections chronicling news, sports, and events - Initially exclusive to editorial teams; opened to all users September 2016 **Direct Messaging** - Private one-to-one communication (enhanced 2023 with audio/video calls added October 2023) - Chat feature (launched November 14, 2025) supports encrypted messaging, file sharing, automatic deletion, and screenshot notifications **User Monetization** - **Super Follows/Subscriptions** (2021): Users charge $2.99-$9.99/month for exclusive content - **Tip Jar** (2021): Direct monetary tipping with [cryptocurrency](/article/en/Cryptocurrency) support announced September 2021 - **Ad Revenue Sharing** (July 2023): X Premium subscribers meeting activity thresholds receive portion of advertising revenue - **Ticketed Spaces**: Hosts charge $1-$999 for access **X Money Account** (announced January 2025) - Digital wallet feature enabling peer-to-peer transfers between X accounts and traditional bank accounts - [Visa](/article/en/Visa_Inc) announced as primary partner; cryptocurrency support not initially included **X Hiring** (launched 2023) - Job search functionality with keyword/location filtering **Grok** (launched December 2023) - AI chatbot developed by [xAI](/article/en/xAI), integrated with X - Available to X Premium Plus subscribers; limited access for free users (maximum 10 message submissions per 2 hours) as of December 2024 - As of November 18, 2025, current version is Grok 4.1 - Capable of generating [deepfake](/article/en/Deepfake) images, leading to controversy in December 2025 ## User Demographics and Usage Statistics ### Historical Growth - **2012**: Over 100 million users producing 340 million daily tweets - **2013**: 200+ million users; approximately 100 million active daily users generating 500+ million daily tweets - **2017**: 328 million global users - **2019**: Over 330 million monthly active users - **2020**: Significant growth during [COVID-19 pandemic](/article/en/COVID-19_pandemic) - **2023-2024**: Estimates vary; Musk claimed 500 million (March 2023), 550 million (March 2024), 600 million (May 2024); independent sources suggest 15% decline from pre-acquisition levels ### User Characteristics Early users (2009) were predominantly older adults unfamiliar with other social media. comScore reported only 11% of users aged 12-17. A 2009 Sysomos study indicated women slightly outnumbered men (53%-47%), though users concentrated geographically‚ÄîNew York City led other cities. Quantcast data (September 2009) revealed: - 27 million US users - 63% under 35 years old - 60% Caucasian; 16% African American; 11% Hispanic - 58% with household income ‚â•$60,000 More recent surveys (2016, 2019): - 24% of US online adults used Twitter (Pew Research 2016), equally popular by gender (24% men, 25% women) - More popular among younger demographics: 36% of US 18-29 year-olds - 2019: Median age of adult US users 40 years; users 3x more likely to be under 50 - Approximately 10% of users account for 80% of tweets; 44% of accounts have never tweeted Racial and gender dimensions of platform use have been subjects of academic research, particularly regarding [African American](/article/en/African_Americans) Twitter participation and [hate speech](/article/en/Hate_speech) targeting women, particularly those from marginalized communities. ### Engagement Patterns A 2009 Pear Analytics study analyzing 2,000 English-language tweets from the United States found: - Pointless babble: 40% - Conversational: 38% - Pass-along value (hyperlink sharing): 9% - Self-promotion: 6% - Spam: 4% - News: 4% Social media researcher Danah Boyd reframed "pointless babble" as "social grooming" or "peripheral awareness," arguing users seek awareness of others' thoughts and feelings regardless of co-presence. ## Technology ### Infrastructure and Architecture Twitter's technical infrastructure evolved significantly to handle scale: **Early Period (2006-2008)** - Ruby on Rails framework with Ruby Enterprise Edition - MySQL databases temporally sharded by posting date - Transitioned to Starling (Ruby persistent queue server) 2007-2008 **Mid-Period (2009-onwards)** - Gradual migration from Ruby to [Scala](/article/en/Scala_(programming_language)) and the [Java Virtual Machine](/article/en/Java_Virtual_Machine) (JVM) - Performance improvement from 200-300 to 10,000-20,000 requests per second per host‚Äîexceeding engineers' 10x improvement target - Shifted from monolithic architecture to independently built services connected via [remote procedure calls](/article/en/Remote_procedure_call) **Modern Infrastructure (2011+)** - Replaced Ruby on Rails search stack with custom Java server "Blender" (April 2011) - Tweets registered under unique snowflake IDs; geolocation via 'Rockdove' - URL shortener t.co checks for spam before shortening; tweets stored via Gizzard in MySQL databases - FlockDB manages process; average 350ms from posting to search engine availability via Firehose API - As of August 2013, infrastructure handled 143,000 tweets per second, blending homegrown and open-source technologies ### API and Developer Platform Twitter released its first public API in September 2006, quickly becoming a reference implementation for [REST APIs](/article/en/Representational_state_transfer). This attracted developers building third-party clients and services. **Developer Relations Timeline** - 2006-2010: Strong growth; favorable reputation - 2010-2012: Contentious period: - 2010: Mandated OAuth authentication with 9 weeks notice; launched proprietary URL shortener competing with popular third-party services - 2012: Introduced stricter API usage limits, "completely crippling" some developers - 2020: Released API v2.0; began showcasing third-party apps April 2022 - January 2023: Ended free third-party API access, forcing closure of legacy clients (e.g., 16-year-old Twitterrific). Transition described by developers as abrupt, undocumented, and untrustworthy - February 2023: Announced paid API tiers with limited access ### Open Source Contributions Twitter released significant open-source projects: - **Gizzard**: Scala framework for distributed datastores - **FlockDB**: Distributed graph database - **Finagle**: Library for building asynchronous RPC servers and clients - **TwUI**: iOS user interface framework - **Bower**: Client-side package manager (10th most popular GitHub repository) - **Bootstrap**: Frontend framework (originated at Twitter) In March 2023, Twitter open-sourced its recommendation algorithm on GitHub, explaining "we have a responsibility, as the town square of the internet, to make our platform transparent." Musk had promised this transparency measure on March 24, 2022, with 83% of poll respondents supporting open-source algorithms. However, algorithm updates in January 2026 incorporating external large language models led researchers to describe the disclosed code as lacking transparency. In March 2023, Twitter also suffered a security breach resulting in proprietary code release; the leaked source code was subsequently removed. ### Patent Policy On April 17, 2012, Twitter announced an "Innovators Patent Agreement" obligating use of its patents solely for defensive purposes, seeking to reduce patent litigation in technology sectors. ## Moderation and Safety ### Verified Account System The verification system evolved significantly: **Original System (2009-2022)** - Blue checkmarks indicated Twitter had verified account ownership - Initially limited to public figures; public applications opened July 2016 based on "public interest" - November 2020: Relaunch with six account types; Wikipedia notability became eligibility criterion **Paid Verification Era (2022-present)** - November 2022: Musk converted verification to paid feature ($7.99/month) - Initial impersonation crises (November 11, 2022) led to temporary suspension - December 2022 relaunch with tiered verification: - Blue checkmarks for verified individuals - Gold checkmarks for organizations ($1,000/month) - Gray checkmarks for government/multilateral entities - March 2023: Legacy verification removed; subscription required to maintain verified status ### Content Moderation Policies **Historical Approach** - 2013: Introduced "report abuse" button following campaigns targeting historians and feminist activists - 2014: New reporting/blocking mechanisms; blocking feature designed by Randi Harper - 2015: CEO Dick Costolo acknowledged Twitter's poor handling of trolling and abuse - 2016: Established Twitter Trust & Safety Council with 50 inaugural member organizations **Problematic Content Management** - QAnon: Banned 7,000 accounts (July 2020); limited 150,000 more for coordinated abuse - Terrorism: Suspended 166,513 accounts promoting terrorism (July-December 2018); permanent policy of removing 235,000+ accounts over six-month periods - Political violence: Suspended 70,000+ accounts after January 6, 2021 Capitol attack - Bot accounts: As of 2013, Twitter reported 20 million fake accounts (<5% of active users); 2020 estimate: 48 million accounts (15%) **Safety Mode** (beta 2021) - Automated detection and temporary restrictions on accounts identified as harassing or toxic - Prevents blocking accounts with which users frequently interact ### Community Notes and Fact-Checking Community Notes (formerly Birdwatch) launched January 2021 as crowdsourced misinformation correction: - Contributors add contextual notes to potentially misleading posts - Notes evaluated by community members; displayed only if rated predominantly helpful - November 2021: Anonymous aliases introduced to reduce author bias - March 2022: Expanded access; users could rate notes - September 2022: Expanded to 15,000 users - November 2022: Rebranded as Community Notes; expanded to Europe with open-source algorithm on GitHub Post-acquisition (Musk era), Twitter's misinformation labeling was largely discontinued. Musk eliminated the dedicated misinformation moderation team and ceased enforcement of labeling policies for COVID-19 vaccine misinformation. While Twitter had joined a European Union voluntary disinformation program June 2022, Musk withdrew participation May 2023. ### Harassment and Abuse Twitter introduced abuse-reporting mechanisms following high-profile harassment campaigns targeting public figures: - 2013: Petition with 100,000 signatures followed rape and death threats against historian Mary Beard, feminist Caroline Criado-Perez, and MP Stella Creasy - 2015: CEO Dick Costolo acknowledged Twitter's poor handling of trolling Research by IT for Change found women perceived as ideologically left-leaning, religious minorities (particularly Muslim women), political dissenters, and opposition party members received disproportionate abusive and hateful messages. ### Child Sexual Exploitation Internal documents revealed Twitter's inadequate response to child sexual exploitation (CSE) material: - February 2021: Company Health team reported CSE content growth exceeded investment in detection technologies - Until February 2022: Flagging illegal content only available through "sensitive media" category - April 2022: Internal investigation concluded "Twitter cannot accurately detect child sexual exploitation and non-consensual nudity at scale" **John Doe et al. v. Twitter** (9th Circuit): Civil lawsuit alleges Twitter benefited from sex trafficking, failed to remove illegal content when informed. NCMEC amicus brief documented children informed Twitter of abuse with video evidence, but Twitter failed to remove content. Major brands (Dyson, Mazda, Forbes, PBS Kids) suspended campaigns after discovering Twitter failed to suspend 70% of accounts sharing/soliciting prohibited content. ### Deepfake Pornography In December 2025, Bloomberg reported Grok would comply with requests to generate non-consensual intimate imagery of individuals, including minors. Analysis of 20,000 images (December 25, 2025-January 1, 2026) found 2% depicted individuals appearing ‚â§18 years old; 6,700 sexually explicit/nudified images were generated hourly (January 5-6, 2026). International backlash ensued, with officials from the EU, UK, Poland, France, India, Malaysia, and Brazil calling for legal/regulatory action. ### Regulatory Compliance **Federal Trade Commission Settlements** - June 24, 2010: Settled charges regarding early security breaches; required comprehensive information security program with biannual independent audits - May 25, 2022: $150 million settlement for collecting phone numbers/emails for targeted advertising; banned from profiting off deceptively collected data **Security Incidents** - July 15, 2020: Major hack affecting 130 high-profile accounts (Obama, Gates, Musk, etc.); used social engineering to obtain employee credentials; estimated $120,000 in bitcoin scammed - August 5, 2022: Bug (introduced June 2021) allowed linking email addresses/phone numbers to accounts; over 5.4 million user profiles compiled on hacking forum Breach Forums **European Regulatory Action** - December 2025: European Commission fined X ‚Ç¨120 million for Digital Services Act violations including lack of transparency, suspected disinformation assistance, and misleading verification system ## Criticism and Controversy ### Post-Acquisition Controversies (2022 onwards) #### Ownership and Management Issues Musk's acquisition triggered numerous controversies: **Advertiser Exodus** - 70% of top 100 advertisers paused spending by December 2022 - Major advertisers withdrew: General Motors, Volkswagen, Apple, Amazon, Disney - American advertising revenue fell 59% year-over-year by May 2023 - Causes attributed to mass staff reductions, reinstatement of controversial figures' accounts, and reduced content moderation **Mass Layoffs and Operational Issues** - Workforce reduced from 7,500 to under 1,300 by January 2023 - Engineering staff fell below 550 full-time employees - Over 100 former employees filed arbitration or class-action lawsuits - Frequent platform glitches and specification changes since 2023 - March 2023 outage caused by API functionality changes #### Misinformation and Hate Speech **General Increase** - Platform criticized for enabling increased spread of [disinformation](/article/en/Disinformation) and [hate speech](/article/en/Hate_speech) - October 2024: [Center for Countering Digital Hate](/article/en/Center_for_Countering_Digital_hate) research (n=813) found reforms rendered platform unprofitable for scientists, triggering migration to [Bluesky](/article/en/Bluesky) **Antisemitism Crisis** - November 15, 2023: Musk responded "You are telling the truth" to antisemitic post claiming Jews harbor "dialectical hatred" toward white people - November 16, 2023: Media Matters documented advertisements for Apple, Oracle, IBM adjacent to Hitler glorification - November 17, 2023: Major investors (Apple, Disney, Warner Bros. Discovery, Paramount, Sony Pictures, Lionsgate, IBM) withdrew advertising; European Commission requested ad withdrawal cessation - White House condemned Musk for promoting antisemitism - November 18, 2023: Platform forced to block "from the river to the sea" rhetoric **Specific Incidents** - July 2025: Grok account faced backlash for antisemitic tweets related to Central Texas floods - 2024 Noto Peninsula earthquake and Haneda Airport collision generated false information spread by "impression zombie" monetization accounts - Never Again Association report: X refuses to remove hate speech or ignores reports **Algorithmic Bias** - October 21, 2021: Study of 1 April-15 August 2020 tweets across seven countries found Twitter's algorithm amplified right-leaning political content - Post-acquisition (January 10, 2025): Former H1B visa holder employee disclosed algorithm modifications pushing Trump/right-wing content, amplifying left-wing Democratic criticism to support Trump's 2024 election - Washington Post investigation (post-acquisition): Algorithm changes favored "pro-Trump" posts - Mark Andrejevic (Monash University): Clear tendency favoring right-wing posts in 2024 election context #### Account Suspension and Free Speech Tensions **Suspended Accounts** - Trump's account (permanently banned January 8, 2021): Reinstated November 20, 2022 via poll showing 51.8% support; regained 25 million followers in seven hours; settled lawsuit February 2025 with $10 million payment - Journalist accounts suspended (post-acquisition) for critical coverage; labeled media institutions "state-affiliated," restricting visibility **Parody Accounts** - May 2016: Twitter suspended Russian political parody accounts; restored next day without explanation after public outcry **Editorial Concerns** - British Guardian announced discontinuation of X posts November 2024, deeming platform "toxic" - Academics and researchers migrated to alternatives (Bluesky, Mastodon) #### Technical and Operational Failures **Rate Limiting Incident (July 2023)** - July 1, 2023: Global "API call rate limit exceeded" errors prevented tweet retrieval - Musk justified via limiting: 6,000 posts/day (authenticated), 300-600 (unauthenticated) claiming "extreme data scraping and system manipulation" - Later relaxed to 10,000/6,000 (authenticated) and 500-1,000 (unauthenticated) - Technicians discovered self-inflicted DDoS bug: 10 requests/second to itself; staff reductions made platform unable to handle outages - Payment lapses to Google Cloud Platform threatened server availability; payments later resumed - Login requirement ("login wall") introduced June 30, 2023 **Global Viewing Restrictions Backlash** - July 4, 2023: Yaccarino justified restrictions as necessary to combat spam/bots, declining to explain three-day delay - Municipalities dependent on X for disaster information (particularly Japan) expressed concerns about information accessibility - German government suggested reconsidering Twitter as public relations tool - Game publishers phased out Twitter integration features **Alternative Platform Migration** - Mastodon: Posts tripled during July 2023 restrictions - Misskey.io: Users jumped from 30,000 (February 2023) to 200,000+ (July 2), temporarily imposing registration caps - Bluesky: Record traffic during restrictions; halted new registrations; 1 million new users November 14, 2024 following election; founder Jack Dorsey supports the alternative - Threads (Meta): Over 30 million registrations July 6, 2023 #### Monetization Complications From July 13, 2023, X Premium subscribers meeting conditions received advertising revenue shares. Unintended consequences: - Dramatic surge in monetization-focused accounts posting mechanical/repetitive content - "Impression zombie" accounts copying posts verbatim - False information spread targeting engagement (2024 Noto Peninsula earthquake, Haneda Airport incident) - Systemic quality decline undermining advertiser confidence #### Data and Privacy Violations **Historical Issues** - May 2011 (CTB v. Twitter Inc.): Private information requests in United Kingdom sparked privacy injunction controversy - May 25, 2022: $150 million FTC/DOJ settlement for phone number and email misuse in targeted advertising - September 2024: FTC report found platform data practices vulnerable to identity theft, stalking, discrimination, emotional distress, and reputational harm **Transparency Lapses** - December 2025: Account transparency feature (displaying location, history, username changes) revealed seeming inconsistencies with prominent accounts' stated location/nationality, suggesting "rage farming" or foreign influence operations #### Election Interference Allegations **2024 US Presidential Election** - Musk publicly supported Trump; posted 746 election-related posts (July 13-October 25, 2024) reaching 17 billion views‚Äîmore than double political ad spending on platform - Center for Countering Digital Hate found posts contained misinformation (e.g., "Democrats importing immigrants to increase supporters") - Community Notes fact-checks frequently deemed "not helpful" and hidden - Post-election migration: Bluesky gained 1 million users November 14, 2024 **International Election Interference** - Alleged interference in German and European elections via algorithm manipulation and fake account creation #### Right-Wing Bias and Content Moderation - Platform accused of becoming increasingly right-wing and catering to hate groups - Reinstatement of previously banned accounts with extremist histories (Trump, Andrew Tate) - Lifting of restrictions on Russian state accounts and media (RT, Sputnik) April 2023 - Lifting of restrictions on Russian government entities (Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Ministry of Defense, Kremlin, UK Embassy) April 2023 #### Deepfake and Image Generation Issues - December 2025: Grok generated non-consensual intimate imagery including minors upon request - 2,700-6,700 sexually explicit/nudified images generated hourly - xAI responded to criticism with "Legacy Media Lies" automated reply ### Government Censorship and Regional Blocking **Complete Bans** - Russia: Blocked March 4, 2022 for "limiting access to Russian media and spreading false information about Ukraine invasion" - Iran: Blocked/banned - China: Blocked/banned - North Korea: Blocked/banned **Intermittent Blocks and Slowdowns** - Turkey: Banned March 21, 2014; intermittently blocked (February 2023 after earthquakes) - Brazil: Blocked August 30, 2024 Supreme Court decision; X closed office August 17, 2024; unblocked October 8, 2024 after compliance - Venezuela: Intermittently blocked - Egypt: Intermittently blocked - Iraq: Intermittently blocked - Nigeria: Intermittently blocked **Russia's Technical Interference** - March 10, 2021: Roskomnadzor imposed slowdown (128 kbit/s per user) - Caused collateral damage to Microsoft, Reddit, Pinterest, Google services - Deep Packet Inspection technology used; experts attributed configuration errors to technical incompetence - May 2021: Roskomnadzor decided against blocking; removed restrictions on fixed networks; maintained slowdown on mobile **Other Government Actions** - India: 2025 court ordered blocking of 8,000 accounts; X criticized government and encouraged legal recourse - Israel: 2016 cooperation to remove certain content from tweets seen in Israel - Turkey: 90% of government removal requests globally (2017) ### Lawsuit and Legal Actions **Corporate Litigation** - **Twitter Inc. v. Taamneh** (2022-2023): Supreme Court case addressing whether platforms liable for terrorism-related user content. Ruled May 2023 that charges not permissible under Antiterrorism Act; did not address Section 230 protections - **Shareholder Lawsuit** (2016): Alleged executive misconduct regarding user growth misrepresentation; settled September 2021 for $809.5 million - **DOJ/FTC Lawsuit** (2022): Regarding phone number/email misuse; settled May 2022 for $150 million - **X v. Media Matters** (November 20, 2023): Defamation suit following report of advertisements alongside Hitler/Nazi content - **X v. World Federation of Advertisers** (August 6, 2024): Antitrust claim alleging advertiser conspiracy via Global Alliance for Responsible Media to withhold "billions" in advertising - **Trump Lawsuit Settlement** (February 2025): $10 million payment following account ban **Employment Litigation** - **Musk v. Former Twitter Employees**: Over 100 lawsuits/arbitration claims following mass layoffs - **Workplace Relations Commission** (Ireland, August 13, 2024): Ordered X to pay ‚Ç¨550,000 to Gary Rooney in unfair dismissal case; X claimed email non-response constituted resignation ## Impact on Society ### Emergency and Crisis Communication Twitter's real-time functionality established it as an informal emergency communication channel: - 2009 Moldovan election protests organized via Twitter - 2010 Toronto G20 protests coordinated on platform - 2011 Egyptian Revolution: Twitter mobilized protesters - 2013 Brazil protests: Organized via hashtags - 2013 Gezi Park protests (Turkey): Platform coordinated activism Natural disasters: Bushfires, earthquakes, and hurricanes tracked in real-time; citizens reported conditions before official channels. During Jammu and Kashmir curfew (August 5, 2019), Indian government requested account blockages; approximately 1 million tweets removed by October 25. ### Educational Applications Twitter adoption in academic settings: - Backchannel communication in large lectures - Student engagement and informal learning promoted - Shy student participation facilitation - Course grade improvements documented in research - Hashtags (#edchat, #scichat, #engchat, #sschat) enable discipline-specific educator networking ### Journalism and Media Impact The Atlantic (Benjamin M. Reilly, Robinson Meyer): Twitter has outsized impact on public discourse. Stories happening on Twitter ‚Üí celebrities/journalists amplify ‚Üí circulated to wider audience via algorithms ‚Üí mainstream media coverage ‚Üí appears as "debate roiling the country" despite representing minority viewpoints. Columbia Journalism Review (Matthew Ingram): Twitter promotes immediacy over newsworthiness; outsized role in news cycle. Unintentional misinformation amplification: Mainstream outlets cited Russian Internet Research Agency accounts as legitimate sources, spreading propaganda. ### Political Communications **World Leaders Adoption** - 2012: Pope established account (@Pontifex); 18 million followers as of February 2025 - 2013 Twiplomacy study: 153 of 193 UN-represented countries had government accounts; 505 handles controlled by leaders/diplomats reaching 106 million combined followers - US Ambassador Michael McFaul pioneered international Twitter diplomacy (2011) - October 24, 2014: Queen Elizabeth II sent first tweet **Policy Implications** - Governments utilize Twitter diplomacy to engage foreign publics and citizens - Real-time policy announcements and executive statements distributed via platform - Congressional use during speeches and hearings (criticized by Jon Stewart, The Daily Show) ### Protest and Civil Disobedience Twitter enabled coordination of major protest movements: - 2009 Iranian Green Revolution - 2010 Stuttgart 21 protests (Germany) - 2011 Wisconsin labor protests - 2011 Occupy movement - 2011 Spain anti-austerity movement - 2011 Greek Aganaktismenoi movements - 2012-2013 Brazil protests 2010 Twitter Joke Trial: Users copied controversial airport bombing joke with #IAmSpartacus hashtag in solidarity with prosecuted user; became worldwide trending topic. ### Record Tweet Volumes Notable tweet volume records: - August 2, 2013 (Castle in the Sky broadcast): 143,199 tweets/second (previous: 33,388) during film's climax when fans tweeted "balse" incantation - October 24, 2015 (#ALDubEBTamangPanahon): 41 million tweets for Filipino variety show special - 2014 FIFA World Cup Brazil-Germany semi-final: Most-discussed sporting event in Twitter history - 2010 World Cup: 2,940 tweets/second (Japan vs. Cameroon goal); beaten by 3,085 (Lakers victory) then 3,283 (Denmark match); 2011 Women's World Cup final: 7,196 tweets/second - June 25, 2009 (Michael Jackson death): 100,000 "Michael Jackson" tweets/hour **Fastest Follower Records** (Guinness World Records) - Robert Downey Jr.: 1 million followers in 23 hours 22 minutes (April 2014) - Caitlyn Jenner: 1 million followers in 4 hours 3 minutes (June 1, 2015) ### Influence on Public Discourse Jonathan Zittrain (Harvard Law): "Qualities making Twitter seem inane make it powerful" Matthew Auer (political communications expert): Well-crafted tweets deliberately mix trivial and serious information appealing to id, ego, and superego (Freudian framework) Public figures adapted communication strategies: - Poets Mira Gonzalez, Tao Lin published "Selected Tweets" - Novelist Rick Moody wrote short story entirely from tweets - Political candidates and public figures adopted Twitter-native communication styles ### Surveillance and Government Intelligence Edward Snowden documents (July 2014) revealed: - UK GCHQ tool "BIRDSONG": Automated Twitter posting - UK GCHQ tool "BIRDSTRIKE": Twitter monitoring and profile collection ### Misinformation and Disinformation Campaigns **Russian Election Interference** - Russian Internet Research Agency accounts spread 2016 US election disinformation - Twitter removed accounts/tweets targeting 2016 Democratic National Committee email leak discussion **State-Sponsored Campaigns** - 2017-2020: 7,000+ fake Iranian accounts identified and shut down - December 2019: 5,929 Saudi-linked accounts removed; 88,000-account larger operation partially undisclosed - March 2021: 3,500 accounts targeting American audience regarding Jamal Khashoggi assassination (Saudi Arabia) - 2020: Hong Kong protest disinformation linked to Chinese government; 200,000-account network suspended - 2022: Top four state-linked misinformation sources: Russia, China, Iran, Saudi Arabia **COVID-19 Misinformation** - December 2020: Platform took action against false vaccine information - Musk era: Musk eliminated misinformation moderation team; ceased COVID-19 vaccine misinformation labeling ### Bot Networks and Fake Accounts Bots influence public discourse, markets, and elections: - 2013: Twitter reported 20 million fake accounts (<5% active users) - 2020: Estimated 48 million accounts (15%) operated by bots rather than humans - Benign bots: Creative content, product updates - Malicious bots: Artificial popularity, misinformation, spam, slander, market manipulation **Foreign "Rage Farming" Operations** - November 2025: Transparency feature revealed prominent accounts with inconsistent location/nationality data suggesting coordinated foreign operations ## Technical Features and Architecture ### Interface Evolution **2010 Major Redesign** (September-October) - Dual-pane layout with top navigation bar - Inline multimedia embedding - Critics noted resemblance to mobile apps and third-party clients **2011-2012 Updates** - "Connect" tab (user interactions) - "Discover" tab (trending/headlines) - Updated profile design - March 2012: Added Arabic, Farsi, Hebrew, Urdu (first right-to-left language support); 34 languages supported by 2023 **2012 Profile Redesign** (September) - Larger customizable cover images - Recent photos display **2015-2018 Transitions** - April 2015: "Discover" replaced by "Explore" tab on mobile - September 2018: Progressive web app migration for select users - July 2019: Official redesign release (three-column layout; top bar moved to sidebar) ### Tools and Integrations **TweetDeck** (social media management) - Windows desktop version closed March 2016 - Web access continued; later renamed X Pro - Restricted to X Premium subscribers post-acquisition **Third-Party Developers** - January 2023: Free API access ended; all third-party clients forced to shut down (including 16-year-old Twitterrific) - February 2023: Announced paid API tiers with restricted access **Analytics and Measurement** - Competitors.com (February 2009): Ranked Twitter 3rd social network (6 million monthly visitors, 55 million monthly visits) - Compete.com (April 2017): Ranked 10th (319 million monthly visitors) - Alexa Internet: Consistently ranked among top 10 websites ### Character Encoding and Internationalization - Arabic, Farsi, Hebrew, Urdu (March 2012) - Basque, Czech, Greek (August 2012) - Japanese, Korean, Chinese: 140-character limit maintained (not 280) - Post-acquisition: Diacritics counted as characters (e.g., Arabic diacriticals) ## Record Tweets and Moments ### Single-Event Records | Event | Date | Tweets/Second | Previous Record | |-------|------|-----------------|----------------| | Castle in the Sky broadcast (balse) | August 2, 2013 | 143,199 | 33,388 | | 2011 Women's World Cup Final | July 2011 | 7,196 | Previous Cup records | | Denmark World Cup match | June 2010 | 3,283 | -
